question.text: Many believe that it is important to protect all wild animals, while others think that it is important to protect some, not all of them. Discuss both views and give your own opinion.

questionType.explanation: You must discuss BOTH perspectives equally (protecting all wildlife AND selective protection) and clearly state your own opinion.
requirements: Discuss reasons for protecting all wild animals
Discuss arguments for selective wildlife protection
Provide specific examples for each view

keyWords.definition: To keep safe from harm or extinction
keyWords.importance: Central action verb - shows what should be done

keyWords.definition: Every species living in natural habitats
keyWords.importance: This is one main perspective you must discuss
This is the contrasting perspective you must discuss
Signals you MUST discuss both sides equally
You must take a clear position - don't be too neutral

essayStructure.introduction: 2-3 sentences: Paraphrase question + state your opinion
essayStructure.body1: 4-5 sentences: Discuss first view (protecting all animals)
essayStructure.conclusion: 2 sentences: Summarize both views + restate opinion

commonMistakes: Only discussing one side in detail
Opinion is unclear or too balanced ('both are valid')
Forgetting to give concrete examples of species
Copying words directly from the question
Not explaining WHY protection is important

academicVocabulary.definition: The protection and preservation of natural resources.
academicVocabulary.example: Wildlife conservation requires substantial financial resources and expertise.

academicVocabulary.definition: The variety of life in a particular habitat or ecosystem.
academicVocabulary.example: Protecting all species helps maintain biodiversity in ecosystems.

academicVocabulary.definition: A biological community of interacting organisms and their environment.
academicVocabulary.example: Each species plays a crucial role within its ecosystem.

academicVocabulary.definition: To organize by order of importance.
academicVocabulary.example: Conservation efforts should prioritize endangered species facing imminent extinction.

academicVocabulary.definition: The complete disappearance of a species.
academicVocabulary.example: Many species face extinction due to habitat loss and climate change.

academicVocabulary.definition: To distribute resources for a particular purpose.
academicVocabulary.example: Limited funds must be allocated wisely among conservation projects.

academicVocabulary.definition: Having parts that are joined or linked together.
academicVocabulary.example: All species are interconnected within their natural environments.
Wildlife protection requires substantial financial investment and human resources.

topicVocabulary.definition: Animals at serious risk of extinction.
topicVocabulary.example: Pandas and tigers are classified as endangered species requiring urgent protection.

topicVocabulary.definition: The damage or elimination of natural living environments.
topicVocabulary.example: Habitat destruction is the primary threat to wildlife worldwide.

topicVocabulary.definition: Money, personnel, and materials dedicated to protecting wildlife.
topicVocabulary.example: Conservation resources are limited and must be used strategically.

topicVocabulary.definition: The natural equilibrium in an ecosystem.
topicVocabulary.example: Protecting all species helps maintain ecological balance in nature.

topicVocabulary.definition: Species that have disproportionate effects on their ecosystem.
topicVocabulary.example: Wolves are keystone species whose presence affects entire ecosystems.
Limited funding forces conservationists to make difficult choices about which species to protect.

content.instructions: Build sentences you can use in your essay. Complete templates by choosing the right words. These sentences are organized by function - save the ones you complete correctly to use in Step 6!

exerciseSections.title: Thesis Statements (Introduction)
exerciseSections.description: Complete sentences that state both views and your opinion

exercises.template: While some believe _____, others argue that _____.

options: resources should focus on endangered species
blanks.correctAnswer: resources should focus on endangered species

exercises.correctSentence: While some believe all wildlife deserves equal protection, others argue that resources should focus on endangered species.

options: a selective approach is more practical
blanks.correctAnswer: a selective approach is more practical

exercises.correctSentence: In my opinion, a selective approach is more practical because conservation resources are limited.

exercises.template: There is ongoing debate about whether _____ or _____.

options: efforts should prioritize critically endangered animals
blanks.correctAnswer: efforts should prioritize critically endangered animals

exercises.correctSentence: There is ongoing debate about whether every species should receive protection or efforts should prioritize critically endangered animals.

options: the ethical importance of all species
blanks.correctAnswer: the ethical importance of all species

exercises.correctSentence: From my perspective, prioritization is necessary despite the ethical importance of all species.

exercises.template: This essay will discuss _____ before concluding that _____.
exercises.correctSentence: This essay will discuss both perspectives before concluding that strategic conservation is most effective.

exerciseSections.title: Topic Sentences (Body Paragraphs)
exerciseSections.description: Start each body paragraph with a clear topic sentence

exercises.template: On the one hand, _____ argues that _____.
exercises.correctSentence: On the one hand, the universal protection perspective argues that all species have intrinsic value.

exercises.template: On the other hand, _____ contend that _____.
exercises.correctSentence: On the other hand, advocates of selective conservation contend that limited resources require prioritization.
One significant reason for protecting all species is the interconnected nature of ecosystems.

exercises.template: A key argument for _____ is that _____.

options: conservation budgets are insufficient for universal protection
blanks.correctAnswer: conservation budgets are insufficient for universal protection

exercises.correctSentence: A key argument for prioritizing certain species is that conservation budgets are insufficient for universal protection.

exercises.template: _____ argue that _____ plays a vital role in _____.
exercises.correctSentence: Supporters of universal protection argue that every species plays a vital role in maintaining ecological balance.
Proponents of selective conservation maintain that critically endangered species should receive priority in conservation efforts.

options: the moral obligation to preserve biodiversity
blanks.correctAnswer: the moral obligation to preserve biodiversity

exercises.correctSentence: The primary justification for protecting all wildlife is the moral obligation to preserve biodiversity.

options: the enormous financial and logistical demands
blanks.correctAnswer: the enormous financial and logistical demands

exercises.correctSentence: A major challenge with universal wildlife protection is the enormous financial and logistical demands.

exerciseSections.title: Supporting Arguments (Body Paragraphs)
exerciseSections.description: Explain WHY with reasons and analysis

exercises.correctSentence: This is because ecosystems are fundamentally interconnected and interdependent.

exercises.template: The main reason is that _____ forces _____ to _____.
exercises.correctSentence: The main reason is that limited funding forces conservationists to make strategic choices.

options: The loss of even seemingly minor species
blanks.correctAnswer: The loss of even seemingly minor species

exercises.correctSentence: The loss of even seemingly minor species can have cascading effects on entire food chains.

options: maximize the impact of limited resources
blanks.correctAnswer: maximize the impact of limited resources

exercises.correctSentence: Prioritizing endangered species enables conservation organizations to maximize the impact of limited resources.

options: preserve ecosystem services that benefit humanity
blanks.correctAnswer: preserve ecosystem services that benefit humanity

exercises.correctSentence: By protecting biodiversity, we can preserve ecosystem services that benefit humanity.
Strategic allocation of funds allows organizations to prevent immediate extinctions effectively.

options: maintaining the complex web of life
blanks.correctAnswer: maintaining the complex web of life

exercises.correctSentence: Universal protection contributes to environmental stability by maintaining the complex web of life.
Selective conservation ensures that species facing imminent extinction receive urgent attention and adequate resources.

options: a rich and diverse natural heritage
blanks.correctAnswer: a rich and diverse natural heritage

exercises.correctSentence: Protecting all species provides future generations with a rich and diverse natural heritage.

exercises.template: With limited resources, _____ can _____ more effectively.
exercises.correctSentence: With limited resources, targeted conservation programs can save species from extinction more effectively.
As a result, comprehensive wildlife protection helps maintain healthy ecosystems.
Consequently, focused conservation achieves measurable results through efficient use of available funding.

exerciseSections.title: Examples & Evidence
exerciseSections.description: Support your arguments with specific examples

exercises.correctSentence: For instance, many plant species depend on specific insects for pollination and reproduction.
For example, the giant panda receives substantial conservation funding because it faces imminent extinction.

options: how one species can restore ecosystem balance
blanks.correctAnswer: how one species can restore ecosystem balance

exercises.correctSentence: Specifically, the reintroduction of wolves in Yellowstone National Park illustrates how one species can restore ecosystem balance.

options: achieve maximum impact with limited budgets
blanks.correctAnswer: achieve maximum impact with limited budgets

exercises.correctSentence: Research shows that conservation organizations must prioritize funding to achieve maximum impact with limited budgets.

exercises.template: A study by _____ found that _____ are essential for _____.
exercises.correctSentence: A study by environmental scientists found that even small organisms are essential for maintaining ecosystem health.
In particular, critically endangered species such as Sumatran rhinos and Amur leopards require immediate and intensive conservation action.

exercises.template: Many _____, including _____, play crucial roles in _____.
exercises.correctSentence: Many overlooked species, including bees and earthworms, play crucial roles in supporting agricultural systems.

exercises.template: Take _____ as an example: _____ has successfully _____.

options: brought the species back from near extinction
blanks.correctAnswer: brought the species back from near extinction

exercises.correctSentence: Take the California condor recovery program as an example: targeted conservation has successfully brought the species back from near extinction.
According to ecologists, protecting keystone species prevents ecosystem collapse.

options: resources target the most threatened species
blanks.correctAnswer: resources target the most threatened species

exercises.correctSentence: Evidence suggests that focused conservation generates better outcomes when resources target the most threatened species.

exerciseSections.title: Counter-arguments & Concessions
exerciseSections.description: Acknowledge the other side's valid points

exercises.template: However, it could be argued that _____ is _____ given _____.
exercises.correctSentence: However, it could be argued that protecting all species equally is impractical given current financial constraints.
Despite these advantages, selective conservation risks overlooking species that may prove ecologically important later.
Nevertheless, comprehensive protection requires vast resources that most nations cannot currently provide.

exercises.template: Although _____ offers benefits, it _____ the risk of _____.
exercises.correctSentence: Although prioritization offers benefits, it carries the risk of losing biodiversity permanently.

exercises.template: Critics point out that _____ may _____ if _____.
exercises.correctSentence: Critics point out that focusing only on endangered species may cause unforeseen ecological damage if other important species are neglected.
In conclusion, while all species have ecological value, I believe practical limitations necessitate prioritization.
Overall, universal protection emphasizes ecological integrity, whereas selective conservation prioritizes practical effectiveness.
To summarize, effective wildlife conservation requires balancing between ecological ideals and practical constraints.

options: recognizing the value of all wildlife
blanks.correctAnswer: recognizing the value of all wildlife

exercises.correctSentence: Ultimately, conservation strategies should focus on critically endangered species while recognizing the value of all wildlife.

exercises.template: In my view, _____ represents the most viable approach because _____.

options: it maximizes conservation impact within realistic budgets
blanks.correctAnswer: it maximizes conservation impact within realistic budgets

exercises.correctSentence: In my view, strategic prioritization represents the most viable approach because it maximizes conservation impact within realistic budgets.

structure.introduction: While some believe [View A], others argue that [View B]. In my opinion, [Your clear position].
structure.body1: On the one hand, [Topic sentence supporting View A]. This is because [Reason/explanation]. For instance, [Specific example]. As a result, [Consequence or benefit].
structure.body2: On the other hand, [Topic sentence supporting View B]. The main reason is [Reason/explanation]. For example, [Specific example]. Therefore, [Conclusion about this view].
structure.conclusion: In conclusion, while [Brief summary of both views], I believe [Restate your position with final thought].

example.introduction: While some believe all wildlife deserves equal protection, others argue that conservation resources should prioritize endangered species. In my opinion, practical constraints require strategic prioritization.
example.body1: On the one hand, universal protection acknowledges that all species play important roles in ecosystems. This is because even small organisms contribute to ecological balance. For instance, bees are essential for pollinating crops and wild plants. As a result, protecting all species helps maintain environmental stability.
example.body2: On the other hand, selective conservation enables more effective use of limited resources. The main reason is that conservation budgets cannot cover all species equally. For example, focusing on critically endangered pandas has saved them from extinction. Therefore, targeted efforts achieve measurable results.
example.conclusion: In conclusion, while all species have ecological value, I believe practical limitations require prioritizing those facing imminent extinction to maximize conservation impact.

structure.introduction: There is ongoing debate about [Topic]. From my perspective, [Your opinion], although [acknowledge opposite view].
structure.body1: [Your main view - Topic sentence]. Firstly, [Reason 1]. Secondly, [Reason 2]. For example, [Supporting example].
structure.body2: Nevertheless, [Opposite view - Topic sentence]. [Explanation of why others hold this view]. However, [Counter-argument or limitation].
structure.conclusion: To summarize, despite [opposite view], [restate your position] because [final reason].

structure.introduction: [Restate topic]. This essay will discuss both perspectives and explain why [your position].
structure.body1: Supporters of [View A] point to several benefits. The primary advantage is [Main benefit]. This leads to [Effect/consequence]. Additionally, [Secondary benefit with example].
structure.body2: Conversely, advocates of [View B] emphasize different advantages. Chief among these is [Main benefit]. This results in [Effect/consequence]. Furthermore, [Secondary benefit with example].
structure.conclusion: In conclusion, both approaches offer distinct advantages. However, [your final judgment based on context or priorities].

presenting_first_view: Supporters of universal protection argue that
Advocates of comprehensive conservation contend that
presenting_second_view: Proponents of selective conservation argue that

steps.title: Build Paragraphs
steps.completionCriteria: Complete all 4 paragraphs (10+ words per blank)

content.instructions: Fill in each blank to build your essay paragraph by paragraph. Aim for 10-15 words per blank. Click 'Show Hint' if you need help.

paragraphs.name: Introduction
paragraphs.template: While some _____ [state the first view about protecting all animals], others _____ [state the opposite view about selective protection]. In my opinion, _____ [clearly state YOUR position].

blanks.label: First view about protecting all animals
blanks.hint: Start with 'believe that all wildlife' or 'argue that every species'
blanks.placeholder: e.g., believe that all wildlife species deserve equal protection regardless of their perceived importance

blanks.label: Opposite view about selective protection
blanks.hint: Use 'argue that' or 'contend that' followed by prioritization benefits
blanks.placeholder: e.g., contend that conservation resources should prioritize critically endangered species facing immediate extinction

blanks.label: Your position
blanks.hint: Be clear! Don't say 'both are valid'. Take a position or say 'it depends on...'
blanks.placeholder: e.g., practical limitations require strategic prioritization while acknowledging the ecological value of all species

paragraphs.name: Body Paragraph 1
paragraphs.template: On the one hand, _____ [topic sentence about universal protection]. This is because _____ [explain the reason]. For instance, _____ [give a specific example]. As a result, _____ [state the consequence or benefit].

blanks.label: Topic sentence - universal protection advantages
blanks.hint: Main benefit of protecting all species in one sentence
blanks.placeholder: e.g., protecting all wildlife species helps maintain biodiversity and ecological balance in natural environments

blanks.label: Explain the reason
blanks.hint: WHY does universal protection provide this benefit? Explain the mechanism.
blanks.placeholder: e.g., ecosystems are interconnected and even seemingly minor species play crucial roles in food chains

blanks.label: Specific example
blanks.hint: Give a concrete example - specific species, ecosystem, or scientific study
blanks.placeholder: e.g., bees and other pollinators are essential for agriculture and many plants depend entirely on them for reproduction

blanks.label: Consequence/benefit
blanks.hint: What is the final outcome or impact of this benefit?
blanks.placeholder: e.g., comprehensive protection preserves ecosystem services that benefit both wildlife and human populations

paragraphs.name: Body Paragraph 2
paragraphs.template: On the other hand, _____ [topic sentence about selective protection]. The main reason is _____ [explain why]. For example, _____ [specific example]. Therefore, _____ [conclusion about this perspective].

blanks.label: Topic sentence - selective protection advantages
blanks.hint: Main benefit of prioritizing certain species. Use contrasting language.
blanks.placeholder: e.g., selective conservation enables more effective use of limited financial and human resources

blanks.label: Explain why
blanks.hint: Explain the mechanism or reasoning behind this benefit
blanks.placeholder: e.g., conservation budgets are insufficient to protect every species equally and prioritization maximizes impact

blanks.label: Specific example
blanks.hint: Concrete example showing targeted conservation success
blanks.placeholder: e.g., focused efforts on giant pandas and California condors have successfully brought these species back from near extinction

blanks.label: Conclusion about this view
blanks.hint: Wrap up this perspective with a concluding thought
blanks.placeholder: e.g., strategic allocation of resources prevents immediate extinctions more effectively than spreading funding too thinly

paragraphs.name: Conclusion
paragraphs.template: In conclusion, while _____ [briefly summarize both views], I believe _____ [restate your opinion with a final thought or recommendation].

blanks.label: Summarize both views
blanks.hint: One sentence mentioning both universal and selective protection advantages
blanks.placeholder: e.g., all species contribute to ecological health and selective conservation enables practical resource management

blanks.label: Restate opinion + final thought
blanks.hint: Clearly restate YOUR position and add a final insight or recommendation
blanks.placeholder: e.g., current financial constraints require prioritizing critically endangered species to achieve measurable conservation success within realistic budgets

content.instructions: Now combine your paragraphs into a complete essay. You can copy from Step 5 and edit, or write fresh. Aim for 250-280 words total.

body1.purpose: Discuss universal protection view with reasons and examples

body2.purpose: Discuss selective protection view with reasons and examples

checklist: Introduction clearly states both views and your opinion
Body paragraph 1 discusses universal protection with examples
Body paragraph 2 discusses selective conservation with examples
Conclusion summarizes both views and restates opinion
Variety of sentence structures (simple, compound, complex)
Linking words used to connect ideas

modelEssay.text:
People have differing views about whether all wildlife species deserve protection or if conservation efforts should focus selectively on certain animals. While both perspectives have merit, I believe that practical limitations necessitate a strategic approach that prioritizes the most endangered species.

On the one hand, advocates of universal protection argue that all species play vital roles within their ecosystems. Even organisms that appear insignificant can have profound effects on environmental stability, as ecosystems are fundamentally interconnected and interdependent. For instance, the decline of bee populations threatens not only wild plant reproduction but also agricultural systems that humanity depends upon. Furthermore, protecting biodiversity preserves genetic resources that may prove valuable for medicine, agriculture, or climate adaptation. Consequently, comprehensive wildlife protection helps maintain the complex ecological balance that supports all life on Earth.

On the other hand, selective conservation offers practical advantages given the reality of limited resources. Conservation organizations face substantial financial constraints that make universal protection unfeasible, forcing difficult choices about resource allocation. Targeted programs focusing on critically endangered species, such as the successful California condor and giant panda recovery efforts, demonstrate how concentrated investment can prevent immediate extinctions. Moreover, prioritizing species facing imminent extinction allows conservationists to achieve measurable results rather than spreading resources too thinly across countless species. This strategic approach maximizes the impact of available funding and expertise.

In conclusion, while all species contribute to ecological integrity, practical constraints require prioritizing those facing the greatest extinction risk. Conservation strategies should focus limited resources on critically endangered animals while working gradually toward broader protection as funding and capacity increase.

structure.introduction: People have differing views about whether all wildlife species deserve protection or if conservation efforts should focus selectively on certain animals. While both perspectives have merit, I believe that practical limitations necessitate a strategic approach that prioritizes the most endangered species.
structure.body1: On the one hand, advocates of universal protection argue that all species play vital roles within their ecosystems. Even organisms that appear insignificant can have profound effects on environmental stability, as ecosystems are fundamentally interconnected and interdependent. For instance, the decline of bee populations threatens not only wild plant reproduction but also agricultural systems that humanity depends upon. Furthermore, protecting biodiversity preserves genetic resources that may prove valuable for medicine, agriculture, or climate adaptation. Consequently, comprehensive wildlife protection helps maintain the complex ecological balance that supports all life on Earth.
structure.body2: On the other hand, selective conservation offers practical advantages given the reality of limited resources. Conservation organizations face substantial financial constraints that make universal protection unfeasible, forcing difficult choices about resource allocation. Targeted programs focusing on critically endangered species, such as the successful California condor and giant panda recovery efforts, demonstrate how concentrated investment can prevent immediate extinctions. Moreover, prioritizing species facing imminent extinction allows conservationists to achieve measurable results rather than spreading resources too thinly across countless species. This strategic approach maximizes the impact of available funding and expertise.
structure.conclusion: In conclusion, while all species contribute to ecological integrity, practical constraints require prioritizing those facing the greatest extinction risk. Conservation strategies should focus limited resources on critically endangered animals while working gradually toward broader protection as funding and capacity increase.

highlights.text: On the one hand... On the other hand
highlights.explanation: Classic structure for discussing two contrasting views
Adds another supporting point in second paragraph

highlights.text: the decline of bee populations threatens not only wild plant reproduction but also agricultural systems
highlights.explanation: Specific, concrete example that supports the argument
Academic language showing range of vocabulary
Less common word meaning 'not practical or possible'
